key_points: Two suicide bombers and gunmen attacked crowds at Kabulâ€™s airport, killing at least 60 Afghans and 13 U.S. troops.
The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the airport attack.
U.S. President Joe Biden vowed to retaliate against the perpetrators, saying 'We will hunt you down and make you pay'.
General Frank McKenzie of U.S. Central Command assured that evacuations would continue despite the attacks.
The Taliban condemned the blasts and was not believed to be involved in the attack.
More than 140 Afghans were wounded in the blasts.
An Italian charity, Emergency, reported receiving at least 60 patients wounded in the airport attack.
Pentagon spokesman John Kirby and Gen. McKenzie acknowledged a security breach at the airport.
Several countries advised against going to the Kabul airport due to unspecified security threats.
The attacks occurred amidst efforts to evacuate people following the Taliban's takeover and ahead of the U.S. withdrawal deadline of Aug. 31.
spokespersons: Gen. Frank McKenzie (Head, U.S. Central Command)
Marco Puntin (Manager in Afghanistan, Emergency charity)
